it wasn't revolu AR clothing studies
doesn't really exist in the universities
in which I have taught um but I became
really interested in it when I was
working on my first book which was on

94 the reign of terror which was the
really radical phase of the French

this discourse against luxury luxury was
associated with the Anan regime it was
associated with the aristocratic class
it was is associated especially with
Maran tette this frivolous beautifully
bedek figurehead at the at the Apex of a

there was a lot of discussion in these

can and and I started coming across very

somebody like RBIs Pierre the the head

otherwise between Barack and and RBIs

language was that specific that robis

Styles and all of the terms were very

are styles that don't exist anymore so
people would complain viciously about
Maran tet's Harpy hairess or about her
poof contol the counterrevolutionary
poof and what the hell were those things
and so I went back to the kind of

styles to decode what these fashion

Revolution and what I found out was that
Mar Antoinette had spent her entire life
essentially stirring up controversy and
making political statements through her
clothing choices uh when she first got
to France when she was only 15 years old
and she was married off to the Future
King the future Louis the 16th she was a
viese princess had never set foot on
French soil and she caused all kinds of
commotion in the court of vers by
refusing to wear a corset she was young
she was skinny she had a great figure
the the kind of Court ball gown was this
very structured thing with a tight waist
and a huge inflated hoop skirt and low
cut with lots of lace she didn't need a
corset to fit into it but what she
quickly was told by alarmed people in
very high positions like the Austrian
ambassador to France and like the king
himself
the corset was a sign of prestige at the
court of versailes and in fact the more
powerful you were within the court
hierarchy the bigger and batter and
Tighter your corset had to be so Maran
tette was not only expected to wear a
corset she was expected to wear the most
constrictive one of them all it was
called the gor only princesses of the
blood and Royals were allowed to wear it
and it was so painful and restraining
that people fainted in it all the time
maret's best friend was a princess of
the blood named the princess de Lal and
she was F famous for fainting every time
someone told a funny story because she
didn't get enough oxygen to laugh so Mar
an tonette was told at a certain moment
within her first year at Versailles you
you have to keep wearing the corset this
is a problem of which all of France is
complaining and so she learned very
young very soon in her time in France
that all of France was looking at her
clothing choices and she went from that
being something of which she became sort
of a victim where she was constantly
getting yelled at for these sort of
breaches of of sartorial etiquette to
something that she used to try to
express herself and make bids for
authority and power at a time when she
was in fact a very unpopular princess
and a very unpopular Queen and this long
precedes the idea of let them meat cake
Maran tette was unpopular before she
ever showed up in France because she was
Austrian and the French did not want an
Austrian woman on the throne Austria had
been an enemy of France for centuries
before this arranged marriage that was
designed to establish a new peace
between the two countries some Mar
Anette nobody wanted her at court even
her own husband who was supposed to get
her pregnant so they could have these
children and Shore up the the bourbon
Dynasty her own husband hated austrians
had been taught that austrians were the
source of all evil in the world that
they had poisoned both of his parents
which wasn't true his parents had died
of small poox or tuberculosis or
something like that but he had been
taught that austrians were murderers
who' killed his parents so nobody wanted
her around her husband didn't sleep with
her for the first seven years of their
marriage and she was in this position
where because everybody wanted her gone
because she wasn't even carrying a royal
air that could kind of help her justify
her Presence at court she decided to use
clothing to establish basically a facade
of authority where she didn't have any
uh one of the most interesting things
she did while she was still a teenager
was she started wearing men's riding

exceedingly uncommon at the court of
versailes everything at the court of
Versa was ritualized everything was
prescribed and women rode Sid saddle in
these very beautiful flowing skirts and
and very feminine outfits Maria tette
dressed like a man to ride and uh if you
look at a contemporary portrait from

and she had copies sent to the courts
all over Europe where everybody was
gossiping that she was going to get

like Louis the 14th uh posing arride his
horse so she seemed to be kind of
Reinventing herself as a powerful King
and this imagery was especially powerful
and interesting because Mar an tette
herself was related to Louis the 14th
the greatest King that modern France had
ever known so she seemed to be posturing
in a way to say don't mess with me I
have every right to be in this AUST
position and really for the rest of her
life she used clothing in that way to
provoke the public to assert power that

believe that she had and that was what
was really so interesting for me about
her story was that her clothing was much
more than just a kind of a hobby that a
frivolous not particularly intelligent
woman spent a lot of time busying
herself with because she didn't have
anything better to do people often
compare uh Maria tette to Princess Diana
for that reason but what I tried to show
in Queen of fashion is that Maria tette
had very strong political reasons for
and Maran tette faced very strong
political repercussions for the kinds of
costuming selections that she
made yeah you know this idea a of of the

Our Fate is a really interesting one and

used only the favorite presidential

to the media it was a very different
very modern kind of self-fashioning that

might even say more than ever because

there's now a whole culture where

how many blogs had things to say about

could say that that our clothing and Our
Fate are more intricately intertwined

that we do live in America and in

the case before the French Revolution
for instance in 18th century France
there were still very rigid guidelines
for who from what class was allowed to
wear what so for instance if you were a
commoner slaving away in a field
somewhere you would never be seen

very much in place in a lot of European
countries and even when they weren't in
place
people ask me a lot who the Maran
tonette of our time is and and my answer
sort of changes depending on my mood and
the the serious answer is that there
can't be a mar Antoinette of our time
for some of the reasons that I've

choices Maran twinette made about the

introduced for instance the three- foot

it was heavily powdered flour was one of
the one of the ingredients of this
powder and so her headdresses were seen

I think that we could look at a figure

and this is she sells records we all

Wild Child becoming the first lady of
